born 20 November 1987) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]].<ref name="htafc_2018-06-01">{{cite news | date= 1 June 2018 | url= https://www.htafc.com/news/2018/june/transfer-ben-hamer-to-join-town-on-1-july/ |title=TRANSFER: BEN HAMER TO JOIN TOWN ON 1 JULY | accessdate= 1 June 2018}}</ref>
==Career== ===Early career=== Hamer was born in [[Chard, Somerset]] and is a [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] fan.<ref>{{cite news | date= 11 September 2012 | url= http://www.southlondon-today.co.uk/Sport.cfm?id=31431&headline=Ben | title= Ben Hamer can't wait for Charlton derby test | work= southlondon-today.co.uk/Sport | accessdate= 11 September 2012 | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20131216005849/http://www.southlondon-today.co.uk/Sport.cfm?id=31431&headline=Ben | archivedate= 16 December 2013 | df= dmy-all}}</ref> His family moved to Germany at the age of 3 and, consequently, he is a fluent German speaker. However, when he was 8, his family came back to England. He attended Holyrood Community School in Chard which is near to his birthplace. His footballing ability led to a spell playing for [[Somerset]] at county level, where he was spotted by a Reading scout. He signed for Reading at the age of 15.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}}
===Reading=== ====Loan to Crawley Town==== Having risen through the youth academy at [[Reading F.C.|Reading]], Hamer went on loan to [[Crawley Town F.C.|Crawley Town]] for the [[2006–07 in English football|2006–07]] season, where he missed just one league game and was named as Player of the Season.<ref>{{cite news | date=9 October 2006 | url=http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~908887,00.html | archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805125113/http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~908887,00.html | dead-url=yes | archivedate=5 August 2012 | title=Osano impresses as a number of youngsters benefit from current loans | publisher=Reading F.C. | accessdate=9 October 2006}}</ref>
====Loans to Brentford==== On 4 July 2007, Hamer signed a new one-year contract to keep him at Reading until the end of the [[2007–08 in English football|2007–08]] season.<ref>{{cite news | date=4 July 2007 | url=http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1067116,00.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080411130459/http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~1067116%2C00.html | archivedate=11 April 2008 | title=Four new contracts agreed | publisher=Reading F.C. | accessdate=7 July 2007 | deadurl=yes | df=dmy-all}}</ref> He joined [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in an initial one-month loan deal on 11 August 2007,<ref>{{cite news | date=11 August 2007 | url=http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1088849,00.html | archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805154025/http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1088849,00.html | dead-url=yes | archivedate=5 August 2012 | title=Royals agree another loan move | publisher=Reading F.C. | accessdate=13 September 2007}}</ref> which was subsequently extended to 14 October 2007.<ref>{{cite news | date=12 September 2007 | url=http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1110607,00.html | archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805123353/http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1110607,00.html | dead-url=yes | archivedate=5 August 2012 | title=Youngster loan deal extended | publisher=Reading F.C. | accessdate=13 September 2007}}</ref> Brentford re-signed Hamer in an emergency loan deal on 1 January 2008, following an injury to their first choice 'keeper, [[Simon Brown (footballer, born 1976)|Simon Brown]].<ref>{{cite news | date=1 January 2008 | url=http://www.brentfordfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~1203220,00.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080104140406/http://www.brentfordfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10421~1203220%2C00.html | archivedate=4 January 2008 | title=Ben returns | publisher=Brentford F.C. | accessdate=1 January 2008 | deadurl=yes | df=dmy-all}}</ref> On 28 January 2008, his loan was extended to the end of the 2007–08 season.<ref>{{cite news | date=28 January 2008 | url=http://www.brentfordfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~1226609,00.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080409131839/http://www.brentfordfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10421~1226609%2C00.html | archivedate=9 April 2008 | title=Ben's Loan Extended | publisher=Brentford F.C. | accessdate=28 January 2008 | deadurl=yes | df=dmy-all}}</ref>
He signed a new one-year deal with Reading and returned to Brentford for a third loan spell on a season-long loan on 17 June, and was [[Andy Scott (footballer, born 1972)|Andy Scott]]'s first choice goalkeeper for the [[2008–09 in English football|2008–09]] season, in which Brentford were champions of [[Football League Two|League Two]].<ref>{{cite news | date=17 June 2008 | url=http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1329888,00.html | archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805155311/http://www.readingfc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1329888,00.html | dead-url=yes | archivedate=5 August 2012 | title=Hamer signs deal & makes loan move | publisher=Reading F.C. | accessdate=17 June 2008}}</ref> As well as winning a League Two Champions medal, Hamer also won the Puma Golden Glove award for League 2 having recorded 20 clean sheets within the season.<ref>{{cite news | date=21 May 2009 | url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0,,10421~1663230,00.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090526192608/http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10421~1663230%2C00.html | archivedate=26 May 2009 | title=Ben scoops award | publisher=Brentford F.C. | accessdate=22 May 2009 | deadurl=yes | df=dmy-all}}</ref> He was also the only Brentford player to successfully hit the crossbar in [[Soccer AM]]'s Crossbar Challenge.
On 18 June 2009, Hamer signed a new two-year contract and was expected to jostle with [[Adam Federici]] for the Number 1 jersey. On 31 August, Hamer was loaned back to Brentford for a fourth spell with the Bees.<ref>{{cite news | date=18 June 2009 | url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~1694724,00.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120314020741/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~1694724%2C00.html | archivedate=14 March 2012 | title=Hamer signs two-year deal | publisher=Reading F.C. | accessdate=18 June 2009 | deadurl=yes | df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | date=18 June 2009 | url=http://www.getbracknell.co.uk/sport/football/readingfc/s/2052759_ben_hamer_signs_new_reading_fc_deal | title=Exeter City sign Reading keeper Ben Hamer on loan | publisher=getbracknell.co.uk| accessdate=18 June 2009}}</ref>
====Loan to Exeter City==== On 18 January 2011, Hamer joined [[Football League One|League One]] side [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] on a three-month loan deal.<ref>{{cite news | date=19 January 2011 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/e/exeter_city/9366400.stm| title=Ben Hamer signs new Reading FC deal | publisher=BBC Sport| accessdate=19 January 2011}}</ref> Hamer made his [[Exeter City F.C.|Exeter City]] debut against [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] on 22 January 2011.
===Charlton Athletic=== [[File:Ben Hamer 05-05-2012 2.jpg|thumb|upright|Hamer celebrating winning the [[EFL League One|League One]] title with [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] in 2012]]
On 1 August 2011, Hamer joined [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] on a three-year contract and was immediately handed the number one jersey.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10267~2406920,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110919062441/http://www.cafc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10267~2406920%2C00.html |archivedate=19 September 2011 |title=Keeper captured |date=1 August 2011 |publisher=Charlton Athletic F.C. |accessdate=30 June 2012 |deadurl=yes}}</ref> He made his debut on 23 August 2011 against his former club Reading in the [[Football League Cup|League Cup]] first round and helped Charlton to a 2 – 1 win. After some initial nervous performances he cemented his place in the team, making crucial saves throughout Charlton's title winning [[Football League One|League One]] [[2011–12 Charlton Athletic F.C. season|campaign]].{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} He clinched promotion to the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] with [[Chris Powell]]'s side in April 2012, with a 1 – 0 win over [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] and continued to play regularly for the Addicks during the [[2012–13 Charlton Athletic F.C. season|2012–13 season]]. A series of injuries resulted in hamer playing fewer matches in the [[2013–14 Charlton Athletic F.C. season|2013–14 season]].
===Leicester City=== After several weeks of strong speculation about Hamer's move to [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], it was finally confirmed on 22 May 2014, by Hamer himself on social media. Hamer says he made the move to the newly promoted Foxes for the chance to play Premier League football.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/BenHamer21/status/469488874109284352|title=Delighted To Have Joined @OfficialFoxes|author= |date=22 May 2014 |work= |publisher=Ben Hamer|accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref> He made his debut in a 1–0 defeat at home to [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] in a [[Football League Cup|Capital One Cup]] second round tie. Following an injury to [[Kasper Schmeichel]] whilst on international duty, Hamer made his [[Premier League]] debut on 13 September, putting in a very good performance and keeping a clean sheet as Leicester secured a 1–0 win at [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]], their first victory since returning to the Premier League.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29090535|title=Stoke 0–1 Leicester|publisher=BBC Sport|date=13 September 2014}}</ref>
He played his second game for Leicester against Premier League champions, [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in a 0–1 home defeat on 13 December. After playing 7 games for Leicester, Hamer lost his place when on 6 January 2015, Leicester signed experienced goalkeeper [[Mark Schwarzer]] from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] to help cover for the injured [[Kasper Schmeichel]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/leicester-city-sign-mark-schwarzer-2186274.aspx|title=Leicester City Sign Mark Schwarzer|publisher=Leicester City F.C.|date=6 January 2015|accessdate=6 January 2015}}</ref> In the 2016–17 season, Hamer started Leicester's sixth Champions League group game, giving him his Champions League debut. Leicester lost 5–0 to [[FC Porto]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38226552 |title=Champions League - Group G |publisher=BBC Sport |date=7 December 2016}}</ref>
====Loan to Nottingham Forest==== On 25 July 2015, Hamer joined [[Football League Championship|Championship]] side [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] on a season-long loan deal.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Reds secure Hamer |url=http://www.nottinghamforest.co.uk/news/article/reds-secure-hamer-2570519.aspx |publisher=Nottingham Forest F.C. |date=25 July 2015}}</ref> However, he returned to Leicester on 4 August after the loan was cut short due to Nottingham Forest's financial issues.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-goalkeeper-Ben-Hamer-returns/story-27542878-detail/story.html|title=Leicester City goalkeeper Ben Hamer returns from Nottingham Forest loan over financial issues|work=Leicester Mercury|date=4 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150807003235/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-goalkeeper-Ben-Hamer-returns/story-27542878-detail/story.html|archivedate=7 August 2015}}</ref>
====Loan to Bristol City==== On 11 August 2015, Hamer joined Championship side [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on season-long loan deal.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Hamer joins for the season |url=http://www.bcfc.co.uk/news/article/hamer-joins-for-the-season-2609819.aspx? |publisher=Bristol City F.C. |date=11 August 2015 |accessdate=12 August 2015}}</ref> However, he returned to Leicester City on 17 November 2015 after making only five appearances for the club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bcfc.co.uk/news/article/hamer-heads-back-to-leicester-2804490.aspx|title=Hamer heads back to Leicester|publisher=Bristol City F.C. |date=17 November 2015}}</ref>
===Huddersfield Town=== On 1 June 2018, [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] announced the signing of Hamer on a free transfer once his contract ended on 1 July.<ref name="htafc_2018-06-01"/>

(on loan from [[Montpellier HSC|Montpellier]]) | clubnumber = 18 | years1 = 2013–2016 | clubs1 = [[Valenciennes FC#Reserve squad|Valenciennes B]] | caps1 = 30 | goals1 = 3 | years2 = 2015–2016 | clubs2 = [[Valenciennes FC|Valenciennes]] | caps2 = 48 | goals2 = 7 | years3 = 2016–2017 | clubs3 = [[Standard Liège]] | caps3 = 21 | goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2017– | clubs4 = [[Montpellier HSC|Montpellier]] | caps4 = 54 | goals4 = 11 | years5 = 2018– | clubs5 = → [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] (loan) | caps5 = 14 | goals5 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2013 | nationalteam1 = [[Belgium national under-17 football team|Belgium U17]] | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2015 | nationalteam2 = [[Belgium national under-19 football team|Belgium U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2017– | nationalteam3 = [[Belgium national under-21 football team|Belgium U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 12 | nationalgoals3 = 2 | club-update = 10:00, 3 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Isaac Mbenza''' (born 8 March 1996) is a Belgian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] in the [[Premier League]]. He has also represented the Belgian national youth teams until the [[Belgium national under-21 football team|Belgium U21]]. ==Club career== '''Montpellier''' On 31 January 2017, Mbenza signed for French club [[Montpellier HSC|Montpellier]].{{cite web|url=http://www.standard.be/nouvelles-2/lire/~isaac-mbenza-to-montpellier.htm?lng=en|title=Isaac Mbenza to Montpellier|publisher=Standard Liège|date=30 January 2017|access-date=25 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mhscfoot.com/articles/2016-2017/equipe-pro/isaac-mbenza-nouveau-pailladin|title=Isaac Mbenza nouveou Pailladin|publisher=Montpellier HSC|language=fr|date=30 January 2017|access-date=25 May 2017}} '''Huddersfield Town''' On 9 August 2018, Mbenza moved to [[Premier League]] club [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on a season-long loan which had the option to become permanent in summer 2019.{{cite news |title=Loan: winger Isaac Mbenza signs! |url=https://www.htafc.com/news/2018/august/loan-winger-isaac-mbenza-signs/ |publisher=Huddersfield Town A.F.C|date=9 August 2018}} ==International career== Mbenza was born in France and is of Congolese descent, and emigrated to Belgium at a young age.{{cite web|url=http://www.sports.cd/2016/12/14/decouverte-isaac-mbenza-belgo-congolais-de-standard-de-liege/|title=Découverte: Isaac Mbenza belgo-congolais de Standard de Liège !|date=14 December 2016|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://www.voetbalkrant.com/nl/nieuws/lees/2017-03-26/isaac-mbenza-verkiest-belgie-boven-congo|title=België of {{Infobox football biography | name = Laurent Depoitre | image = Zen-Gent15 (6).jpg | fullname = Laurent Depoitre<ref>{{cite web |title=Squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/465277 |publisher=Premier League |date=1 September 2017 |accessdate=9 September 2017}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=y|1988|12|7}} | birth_place = [[Tournai]], Belgium | height = {{height|m=1.91}} | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] | clubnumber = 20 | youthyears1 =1995–2001 |youthclubs1 = AS Montkainoise | youthyears2 =2001–2003 |youthclubs2 = [[R.E. Mouscron|Excelsior Moeskroen]] | youthyears3 =2003–2005 |youthclubs3 = [[R.F.C. Tournai]] | years1 = 2005–2007 | clubs1 = [[R.F.C. Tournai]] | caps1 = 31 | goals1 = 12 | years2 = 2007–2009 | clubs2 = [[R.R.C. Peruwelz|RRC Péruwelz]] | caps2 = 43 | goals2 = 16 | years3 = 2009–2012 | clubs3 = [[SC Eendracht Aalst|Eendracht Aalst]] | caps3 = 69 | goals3 = 25 | years4 = 2012–2014 | clubs4 = [[K.V. Oostende|KV Oostende]] | caps4 = 62 | goals4 = 20 | years5 = 2014–2016 | clubs5 = [[K.A.A. Gent|Gent]] | caps5 = 58 | goals5 = 24 | years6 = 2016–2017 | clubs6 = [[FC Porto|Porto]] | caps6 = 7 | goals6 = 1 | years7 = 2017– | clubs7 = [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] | caps7 = 52 | goals7 = 6 | pcupdate = 09:59, 3 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalyears1 = 2015– | nationalteam1 = [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 1 | nationalteam-update = 21:08, 9 May 2018 (UTC) }} '''Laurent Depoitre''' (born 7 December 1988) is a Belgian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] and the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]].
==Club career== ===Eendracht Aalst=== When a large number of players had to leave Péruwelz after the 2008–09 season, [[Eendracht Aalst]] took advantage of the situation in the summer of 2009 and signed Depoitre alongside Damien Galucci and Olivier De Castro.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Redant|first1=Wim|title=VOETBAL 3DE KLASSE Laurent Depoitre (20) is de nieuwe aanvalsleider van Eendracht Aalst|url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/cnt/s22cq512|publisher=Nieuwsblad|accessdate=11 October 2015|language=Dutch|date=17 July 2009}}</ref> Depoitre formed a good pair in Alost with [[Wouter Moreels]], and he was chosen as the best player of the team after his first season. 2011, the team became champion in [[Belgian Third Division|Third Division]] A. In the 2011–12 season Depoitre was followed by, among other clubs, [[AA Gent]], [[Lierse SK]], [[Oud-Heverlee Leuven]], [[K. Beerschot AC|Beerschot AC]], [[N.E.C.]], [[Sc Heerenveen|Heerenveen]], [[Willem II (football club)|Willem II]] and [[Roda JC]].<ref name="kvo">{{cite web|title=Transfernieuws|url=http://kvo.be/news/detail.phtml?id=1311|publisher=KV Oostende|accessdate=11 October 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420113646/http://kvo.be/news/detail.phtml?id=1311|archivedate=20 April 2013|language=Dutch|date=11 May 2012}}</ref>
===Oostende=== In 2012, Depoitre joined Oostende from Aalst.<ref name="kvo"/><ref name="Sportwereld">{{cite web|last1=Smet|first1=Stefan|title=Laurent Depoitre naar AA Gent|trans-title=Laurent Depoitre to AA Gent|url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/sportwereld/cnt/dmf20140326_01041941|publisher=Sportwereld|accessdate=11 October 2015|language=Dutch|date=26 March 2014}}</ref>
In January 2013, it was announced that he would be transferred to [[SV Zulte Waregem|Zulte Waregem]] in 2013–14. Afterwards, his transfer turned out to be a part of a share transaction between [[Yves Lejaeghere]], the then-president of Ostend, and [[Patrick Decuyper]], the then-general manager of Zulte Waregem.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vandenabeele|first1=Christian|title=Laurent Depoitre: KV Oostende of Zulte Waregem? Of Cercle Brugge?|trans-title=Laurent Depoitre: KV Oostende or Zulte Waregem? Or Cercle Brugge?|url=http://sportmagazine.knack.be/sport/voetbal-nationaal/laurent-depoitre-kv-oostende-of-zulte-waregem-of-cercle-brugge/article-normal-161587.html|publisher=Sport/Voetbal Magazine|accessdate=11 October 2015|language=Dutch|date=10 June 2013}}</ref> In the end the transaction was cancelled and as a result the transfer was also revoked.
===Gent=== After Depoitre decided not to extend his contract with Oostende, it was announced that he would play for KAA Gent during the 2014–2015 season.<ref name="Sportwereld"/>
===Porto=== On 8 August 2016, Depoitre signed for Portuguese club [[FC Porto|Porto]] for four seasons, with €40 million release fee. Porto paid a €6 million transfer fee to [[K.A.A. Gent|Gent]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcporto.pt/en/noticias/Pages/Depoitre-e-reforco-dos-Dragoes-08-08-16.aspx|title=Depoitre reinforces the Dragons|publisher=FC Porto|date=8 August 2016|access-date=8 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Porto telt zes miljoen neer voor Depoitre|url=http://www.hln.be/hln/nl/2725/AA-Gent/article/detail/2824414/2016/08/08/Porto-telt-zes-miljoen-neer-voor-Depoitre.dhtml|accessdate=9 October 2016|work=[[Het Laatste Nieuws]]|date=8 August 2016|language=Dutch}}</ref> He finished the season with 13 appearances across all competitions scoring two goals and providing one assist.<ref name="huddersfield">{{cite news|title=Laurent Depoitre: Huddersfield sign FC Porto striker for record fee|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40389894|accessdate=23 June 2017|publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 June 2017}}</ref>
===Huddersfield Town=== On 23 June 2017, it was confirmed that Depoitre had signed a two-year contract with [[Premier League]] newcomers [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]], for an undisclosed fee, and a record transfer fee for the club.<ref name="huddersfield"/> However, his transfer fee record would go on to be overtaken later that transfer window, by [[Aaron Mooy]] moving from [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] for £8 million.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40289316|title=Aaron Mooy: Huddersfield Town agree club-record £10m fee with Man City|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 June 2017|accessdate=1 July 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.htafc.com/news/2017/june/transfer-aaron-mooy-joins-town-permanently/|title=Huddersfield Town TRANSFER: AARON MOOY JOINS TOWN PERMANENTLY}}</ref>
==International career== On 10 October 2015, he made his senior debut for the national team in a 4–1 win in a UEFA Euro 2016 qualification match against Andorra. Depoitre scored his team's fourth goal.<ref>{{cite web|title=Andorra 1–4 Belgium|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/33543987|publisher=BBC|accessdate=11 October 2015|date=10 October 2015}}</ref>
==Career statistics==
===Club=== {{updated|match played 2 January 2019}}<ref name="Soccerway">{{cite web |url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/laurent-depoitre/92514/ |title=Laurent Depoitre – Soccerway profile |publisher=Soccerway}}</ref><ref name="wf">{{cite web|title=Laurent Depoitre » Club matches|url=http://www.worldfootball.net/player_summary/laurent-depoitre/2/|website=worldfootball.net|accessdate=14 April 2018}}</ref>

| goals3 = 6 | years4 = 2014–2015 | clubs4 = → [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] (loan) | caps4 = 45 | goals4 = 12 | years5 = 2016 | clubs5 = → [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] (loan) | = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps2 = 9 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | club-update = 09:55, 3 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Alex David Pritchard''' (born 3 May 1993) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as an [[Midfielder|attacking midfielder]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]]. He has represented England at [[England national under-20 football team|U20]] and [[England national under-21 football team|U21]] level.
==Career== ===Tottenham Hotspur=== Pritchard began his career in the [[West Ham United F.C. Reserves and Academy|academy]] at [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], before transferring to the [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C. Reserves and Academy|youth setup]] at [[Premier League]] side [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in June 2009.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|author=BST |url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/tottenham-spurs-nextgen-alex-pritchard-coulibaly-384419 |title=The Young Tottenham Trio That Can Challenge for First Team Football |publisher=Ibtimes.co.uk |date=2012-09-14 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> Pritchard quickly established himself in the U18 team.<ref name=":0" /> He received his maiden call into the first team squad for a [[UEFA Europa League]] group stage game versus [[PAOK FC|PAOK]] on 15 September 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/player/165269/alex-pritchard?season=2011 |title=Espn Fc |publisher=Espn Fc |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> Awarded the number 54 shirt, he remained on the bench for the 0–0 draw.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hassan |first=Nabil |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/14832912 |title=BBC Sport – PAOK 0–0 Tottenham |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-09-15 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> He was called up for another Europa League group match versus [[Rubin Kazan]] on 3 November, again remaining on the bench.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bevan |first=Chris |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15472973 |title=BBC Sport – Rubin Kazan 1–0 Tottenham |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2011-11-03 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> Pritchard made an impact in the [[2011–12 NextGen Series]], where he ended up top-scorer for Spurs with four goals, three of which came against the eventual winners [[Inter Milan]]. Pritchard courted transfer interest from Premier League side [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in April 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2128410/Tottenham-reject-QPR-bid-Alex-Pritchard.html|title=Tottenham reject QPR bid for Alex Pritchard – Daily Mail Online|work=Mail Online|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> Pritchard added another four goals in the [[2012–13 NextGen Series|2012–13]] edition of the NextGen Series, one of which came in a particularly notable 4–1 away victory against [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/sites/spurs/News/barca-u19s-spurs-nextgen-report-07112012.page|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121113143649/http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/sites/spurs/News/barca-u19s-spurs-nextgen-report-07112012.page|archivedate=2012-11-13|title=BARCA U19S 1–4 SPURS – SHAQ FIRES LADS TO STUNNING WIN IN NEXTGEN|publisher=tottenhamhotspur.com|date=7 November 2012|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> bringing his tally to eight goals in 11 NextGen Series appearances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/blog/scouts-notebook/78/post/1853497/alex-pritchard-villas-boas-youth-dilemma|title=Alex Pritchard: Villas-Boas' youth dilemma|work=ESPN.com|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> Following Pritchard's NextGen Series performances and with only half a year remaining on his contract, there was speculation that Spanish sides [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and Barcelona would attempt to sign him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2012/11/20/spurs-youngsters-alex-pritchard-and-shaquille-coulthirst-targeted-by-real-madrid-and-barcelona-620619/|title=Spurs youngsters Alex Pritchard and Shaquille Coulthirst targeted by Real Madrid and Barcelona|publisher=metro.co.uk|date=20 November 2012|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] (with Pritchard's former Tottenham U18 manager [[Alex Inglethorpe]] on their staff) were also reported to be interested,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/liverpool-could-snap-up-tottenhams-alex-pritchard-8467157.html|title=Liverpool could snap up Tottenham's Alex Pritchard|publisher=standard.co.uk|date=25 January 2013|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> but Pritchard ended the speculation when he signed a new two-and-a-half-year deal with Spurs on 31 January 2013.<ref name="posh">{{cite web|url=http://www.theposh.com/news/article/20130131-pritchard-joins-from-spurs-631617.aspx|title=Pritchard Joins From Spurs|publisher=theposh.com|date=31 January 2013|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> Pritchard also appeared for Tottenham's U21 team during the 2012–13 season, scoring five goals in 11 appearances to help the U21s to the U21 Premier League knockout stage final against [[Manchester United F.C. Reserves and Academy|Manchester United]]. Pritchard scored Tottenham's second goal and was substituted after 64 minutes for [[Kenny McEvoy]] in the 3–2 defeat.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chase |first=Graham |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2327998/Manchester-United-3-Tottenham-2-Reds-win-Under-21-Premier-League-final-dramatic-comeback-Old-Trafford.html |title=Manchester United 3 Tottenham 2: Reds win Under 21 Premier League final after dramatic comeback at Old Trafford | Mail Online |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2013-05-20 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref>
After spending the majority of the [[2013-14 Tottenham Hotspur F.C. season|2013–14]] season out on loan, Pritchard received his first call into the first team squad in two-and-a-half years when he was named as a substitute for a Premier League match versus his former side West Ham United on 3 May 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/player/165269/alex-pritchard?season=2013 |title=Espn Fc |publisher=Espn Fc |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> Allotted the number 39 shirt, he remained on the bench for the 2–0 defeat.<ref name=":1">[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27168669 "West Ham United 2–0 Tottenham Hotspur"] BBC Sport. 3 May 2014. Retrieved 9 May 2014.</ref> Pritchard was called up again for the final game of the season against [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] and made his debut for the club when he replaced [[Gylfi Sigurðsson]] after 83 minutes of the 3–0 win.<ref>{{cite web|last=Magowan |first=Alistair |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/27273512 |title=BBC Sport – Tottenham Hotspur 3–0 Aston Villa |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2014-05-11 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> After the match, he said "it was good to get my Spurs debut under my belt and to play alongside top quality players. It was a great way to finish the season and hopefully next year I can push on again and get even more game time".<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/debut-caps-fine-season-for-alex-pritchard-140514/ |title=Debut caps fine campaign for Pritchard 14 May 2014 – News |publisher=tottenhamhotspur.com |date=2014-05-14 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> On 21 August 2015, Pritchard agreed to a new four-year contract with Tottenham.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/new-deal-for-pritchard-brentford-loan-170714/ |title=New deal for Pritchard / Brentford loan 17 July 2014 – News |publisher=tottenhamhotspur.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref>
====Peterborough United (loan)==== On 31 January 2013, Pritchard signed on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] with [[EFL Championship|Championship]] side [[Peterborough United F.C.|Peterborough United]] until the end of the [[2012–13 Peterborough United F.C. season|2012–13]] season.<ref name="posh" /> He had scored four goals for the Tottenham Development Squad in an 8–1 victory over Peterborough on 15 January.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/development-squad-81-peterborough-pritchard-grabs-four-in-superb-win-150113/|title=Development Squad 8–1 Peterborough: Pritchard grabs four in superb win|publisher=|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> Awarded the number 33 shirt, Pritchard was named on the bench for a league match versus [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] two days later.<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/player/165269/alex-pritchard?season=2012 |title=Espn Fc |publisher=Espn Fc |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> He made his professional debut when he replaced [[Nathaniel Knight-Percival]] after 55 minutes of the 1–0 defeat.<ref>{{cite web|author=Peterborough 2 Rowe 65′, 69′ |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21209102 |title=BBC Sport – Peterborough 2–2 Burnley |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2013-02-02 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> He came on again as a substitute in the following game against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], but lasted just 16 minutes before suffering torn ligaments in his ankle.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21457948 |title=BBC Sport – Peterborough United suffer from Alex Pritchard injury |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2013-02-14 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> Pritchard returned to Tottenham Hotspur for treatment and didn't appear again for the Posh until a late cameo in a 3–2 victory over [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on 13 April.<ref name=":2" /> He made just six appearances for the club before returning to White Hart Lane at the end of the season.<ref name=":4">{{Soccerbase season|62298|2012|accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref>
====Swindon Town (loan)==== On 9 July 2013, Pritchard joined [[EFL League One|League One]] side [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] on a season long loan deal,<ref name="Swindon Loan">{{cite news|title=Tottenham pair sign as two added to board|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23231972|accessdate=9 July 2013|publisher=BBC Sport|date=9 July 2013}}</ref> linking up with fellow Tottenham loanees [[Massimo Luongo]], [[Grant Hall (footballer)|Grant Hall]], [[Ryan Mason]] and former teammates [[Nathan Byrne]] and [[Jack Barthram]] at the [[County Ground (Swindon)|County Ground]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23423191|title=BBC Sport – Swindon Town: Tottenham's Ryan Mason signs loan deal|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> Wearing the number 11 shirt, Pritchard scored his first goal for the club on 27 August, in a 2–0 win against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] second round.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23764087 "QPR 0–2 Swindon"] BBC Sport. 27 August 2013. Retrieved 28 August 2013.</ref> Pritchard's form led to interest from Championship sides [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]], [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] and League One leaders Wolverhampton Wanderers in January 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisisswindontownfc.co.uk/news/10980429.Town_survive_the_transfer_window_as_star_players_stay_put/?ref=rss|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141211145702/http://www.thisisswindontownfc.co.uk/news/10980429.Town_survive_the_transfer_window_as_star_players_stay_put/?ref=rss|archivedate=2014-12-11|title=Town survive the transfer window as star players stay put|author=Sam Morshead|work=This Is Swindon Town FC|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> Pritchard was [[Ejection (sports)|sent off]] for the first time in his career in a league match versus [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on 15 March, receiving a straight [[Fouls and misconduct (association football)|red card]] for a shove on [[Wade Elliott]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Mitchell |first=Brendon |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/26492996 |title=BBC Sport – Bristol City 0–0 Swindon Town |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date=2014-03-15 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> Earlier in the season, manager [[Mark Cooper (footballer, born 1968)|Mark Cooper]] stated that Pritchard would need to "curb his temper", after he picked up five bookings in seven league matches.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hereisthecity.com/en-gb/2013/09/18/ld-why-is-tottenhams-alex-pritchard-in-trouble-at-swindon/|title=Why is Tottenham's Alex Pritchard in trouble at Swindon?|work=Here Is The City|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> Pritchard won rave reviews for his performances during the season, receiving nominations for the [[Football League Awards|League One Player of the Year]] and [[The Football League|Football League]] Young Player of the Year awards.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11748/9209760/sky-bet-league-one-adam-forshaw-kevin-mcdonald-and-alex-pritchard-up-for-player-prize|title = Sky Bet League One: Adam Forshaw, Kevin McDonald and Alex Pritchard up for player prize | Football News|publisher = Sky Sports|date = |accessdate = 2014-07-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11095/9207718/football-league-will-hughes-liam-moore-and-alex-pritchard-on-young-player-shortlist |title=Football League: Will Hughes, Liam Moore and Alex Pritchard on Young Player shortlist | Football News |publisher=Sky Sports |date= |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> Of the nominations, he said "I'm absolutely chuffed to be nominated, I've worked hard all season and with the amount of players of my age doing so well, it's great to get that recognition".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tottenhamhotspur.com/news/alex-pritchard-on-award-nomination-150314/ |title=Pritchard's pride 15 March 2014 – News |publisher=tottenhamhotspur.com |date=2014-03-15 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> Pritchard was a key player for Swindon over the course of the [[2013–14 Swindon Town F.C. season|2013–14]] season, making 44 appearances and scoring eight goals.<ref name=":5">{{Soccerbase season|62298|2013|accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> Looking back on his time with the Robins, Pritchard said "it was great for me to be playing first team football at Swindon this season, I needed to get out and play competitively and I loved every minute of it".<ref name=":3" />
====Brentford (loan)==== After transfer interest from Wolverhampton Wanderers and [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Howell |first=Bill |url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/wolverhampton-wanderers-transfer-news-tottenham-7255263 |title=Wolverhampton Wanderers transfer news: Tottenham Hotspur youngster on Kenny Jackett's radar |publisher=Birmingham Mail |date=2014-06-12 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> Pritchard signed for Championship side [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] on a season-long loan on 17 July 2014.<ref name=":6">{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/alex-pritchard-loan-17.07.14-1765227.aspx |title=Brentford complete the loan signing of Alex Pritchard from Tottenham Hotspur |publisher=Brentfordfc.co.uk |date=2014-07-15 |accessdate=2014-07-19}}</ref> Manager [[Mark Warburton]] (who helped create the now-defunct NextGen Series) said Pritchard "is very good tactically and technically with excellent dead ball delivery. He showed his quality while he was on loan at Swindon last year. Alex will add to the quality in our squad".<ref name=":6" /> Pritchard scored two goals in a 3–2 [[pre-season friendly]] victory over [[OGC Nice|Nice]] at [[Griffin Park]] on 26 July.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/brentford-v-ogc-nice-psf-26.07.14-1783799.aspx|title=Match report as Brentford beat OGC Nice in pre-season friendly at Griffin Park|author=Chris Wickham|publisher=|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> He made his competitive debut for the club on the opening day of the [[2014–15 Brentford F.C. season|2014–15]] season, lasting 79 minutes of a 1–1 draw with [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] before being replaced by [[Tommy Smith (footballer, born 1980)|Tommy Smith]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28646432|title=BBC Sport – Brentford 1–1 Charlton Athletic|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> Pritchard scored his first competitive goal for the Bees with the equaliser in a 2–1 victory over [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on 19 August.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28750016|title=BBC Sport – Blackpool 1–2 Brentford|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> He scored his second goal a 3–1 win over [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] on 4 October, slotting the ball through [[Adam Federici]]'s legs after [[Andre Gray]] had slipped.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29388656|title=BBC Sport – Brentford 3–1 Reading|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> On 24 January 2015, Pritchard's performance and winning [[Penalty (association football)|penalty]] in a 2–1 win over [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] earned him a place in the Football League Team of the Week.<ref name=":9">{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/alex-pritchard-football-league-team-of-the-week-2228090.aspx|title=Brentford's Alex Pritchard in Football League selection after Norwich City win|author=Mark Chapman|work=brentfordfc.co.uk|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref> Another good performance and a goal in a 3–1 victory over [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] in late February saw him named in the Football League Team of the Week for the second time of the season.<ref name=":10">{{cite web|url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/news/article/2015/sky-bet-football-league-team-of-the-week-2290744.aspx|title=Sky Bet Football League Team of the Week|author=Ryan Percival|work=football-league.co.uk|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref> Pritchard went on a run of four goals in seven games in March and April, but his season ended in disappointment with defeat to [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in the [[2015 Football League play-offs#Championship|playoff semi-finals]].<ref name="Games played by Alex Pritchard in 2014/2015" /> He made 47 appearances and scored 12 goals.<ref name="Games played by Alex Pritchard in 2014/2015" /> Pritchard won much recognition for his performances during the 2014–15 season, winning a place in the Championship [[PFA Team of the Year]],<ref name=PFATOTY1415>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/32473770 |title=PFA Championship Team of the Year: Deeney only Watford player |publisher=BBC Sport |date=26 April 2015 |accessdate=7 May 2018}}</ref> the Brentford Players' and Social Media Player of the Year awards,<ref>{{cite web|title = Alex Pritchard wins Brentford Twitter and Facebook Player of the Year award|url = http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/alex-pritchard-twitter-brentford-player-of-the-year-2464906.aspx|website = www.brentfordfc.co.uk|accessdate = 2015-05-25|first = Ciaran|last = Brett}}</ref> a nomination for the London Football Awards Young Player of the Year award and separate awards for Player of the Year from the Irish and Italian Brentford supporters' clubs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/alex-pritchard-irish-player-of-the-year-2014-15-award-2417791.aspx|title=Alex Pritchard wins Irish Supporters Club Player of the Year Award|author=Mark Chapman|work=brentfordfc.co.uk|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/brentford-london-football-awards-nominations-2298325.aspx|title=London Football Awards nominations for Brentford Manager Mark Warburton and midfield player Alex Pritchard|author=Chris Wickham|work=brentfordfc.co.uk|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/brentford-fc-player-of-the-season-awards-dinner-2438633.aspx|title=Prizes handed out at Brentford FC Player of the Season Awards Dinner|author=Chris Wickham|work=brentfordfc.co.uk|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/alex-pritchard-italian-supporters-award-2444796.aspx|title=Alex Pritchard named Player of the Season for 2014/15 by Brentford's Italian supporters|author=Chris Wickham|work=brentfordfc.co.uk|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref> He was named eighth best Championship player at the [[Football League Awards#2015 Awards|2015 Football League Awards]] and one of the top 20 players in the Football League and 'FL Wonderkid' by ''[[FourFourTwo]]'' and ''[[Match (magazine)|Match]]'' respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/news/article/2015/sky-bet-championship-player-of-the-year-vote-the-top-10-2418695.aspx|title=Sky Bet Championship Player of the Year vote: The top 10|author=The Football League|work=football-league.co.uk|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/brentford-duo-in-fourfourtwo-top-50-football-league-2414790.aspx|title=Brentford's Alex Pritchard and Jota in FourFourTwo top 50 Football League players|author=Chris Wickham|work=brentfordfc.co.uk|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/match-magazine-award-for-brentford-midfield-player-alex-pritchard-2442123.aspx|title=MATCH magazine award for Brentford midfield player Alex Pritchard|author=Chris Wickham|work=brentfordfc.co.uk|accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref>
====West Bromwich Albion==== On 1 February 2016, Pritchard signed for [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Brom]] on loan.<ref>{{Cite web|title = ALBION have completed the loan signing of Tottenham man Alex Pritchard – with the midfielder available to make his debut in tomorrow night's game against Swansea City.|url = http://www.wba.co.uk/news/article/wba-albion-pritchard-2931750.aspx|website = www.wba.co.uk|accessdate = 2016-02-16}}</ref> He made his debut in the 1–0 loss to [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Newcastle United 1–0 West Bromwich Albion|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35447662|website = BBC Sport|accessdate = 2016-02-16|first = Saj Chowdhury BBC|last = Sport}}</ref>
===Norwich City=== On 4 August 2016, Pritchard joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club Norwich City on a four-year deal for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.canaries.co.uk/news/article/2016-17/norwich-city-alex-pritchard-3223305.aspx |title=Alex Pritchard joins City |publisher=Norwich City F.C. |date=4 August 2016 |accessdate=4 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/news/tottenham-sell-pritchard-norwich-city |publisher=FourFourTwo |title=Tottenham sell Pritchard to Norwich City |work=fourfourtwo.com |date=4 August 2016 |accessdate=4 August 2016 }}</ref> However some news agencies such as ''The Mirror'' have reported the fee as being £8,000,000.<ref name="Pritchard-mirror">{{cite web |title=Norwich new boy Alex Pritchard admits "I couldn't wait to get out" after giving up on Tottenham |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/norwich-new-boy-alex-pritchard-8570756 |author=Peter Layton |publisher=The Mirror |date=5 August 2016 |accessdate=20 August 2016}}</ref> Pritchard scored his first goal for Norwich in an [[EFL Cup]] tie against [[Leeds United]] on 25 October 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37686619 |title=Leeds 2–2 Norwich |publisher=BBC |date=25 October 2016 |accessdate=26 October 2016}}</ref> Pritchard scored the final goal in a 5–0 victory over one of his old loan clubs, Brentford, on 3 December 2016.
In the 2017–18 season, Pritchard made nine appearances for Norwich in all competitions, scoring once, after returning from a knee injury that had sidelined him at the start of the season.<ref name="HuddsTown"/>
===Huddersfield Town=== On 12 January 2018, Pritchard joined [[Premier League]] club [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] for an undisclosed fee, signing a three-and-a-half year contract with the Yorkshire club,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.htafc.com/news/2018/january/transfer-alex-pritchard-joins-huddersfield-town/|title= TRANSFER: ALEX PRITCHARD JOINS HUDDERSFIELD TOWN|publisher=Huddersfield Town Football Club|date=12 January 2018}}</ref><ref name="HuddsTown">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42651684|title=Alex Pritchard: Huddersfield Town sign Norwich City midfielder for undisclosed fee|publisher=BBC Sport|date=12 January 2018}}</ref> later estimated to amount to 11M.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/may/10/huddersfield-stay-up-premier-league-david-wagner-money|title=Huddersfield staying up is Premier League’s greatest survival story|last=Doyle|first=Paul|date=2018-05-10|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-12-02}}</ref> His debut versus West Ham United ended in a 4–1 home defeat. [https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42587967] On 11 February, he scored his first Premier League goal in a 4–1 home win over [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]], while also winning a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/42934991|title=Huddersfield Town 4-1 Bournemouth|date=2018-02-11|work=BBC Sport|access-date=2018-02-12|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==International career== On 27 May 2013, Pritchard was named in manager [[Peter Taylor (footballer born 1953)|Peter Taylor]]'s 21-man squad for the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup|2013 U20 World Cup]].<ref>[https://archive.is/20130615071407/http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/u20s-world-cup-squad-announcement-280513 "Final squad named"] TheFA.com. 28 May 2013. Retrieved 17 June 2013.</ref> He made his debut on 16 June, in a 3–0 pre-tournament friendly win over [[Uruguay national under-20 football team|Uruguay]].<ref>[https://archive.is/20130624222816/http://www.thefa.com/england/mens-u20s/News/2013/uruguay-report-160613 "Training win for Three Lions"] TheFA.com. 16 June 2013. Retrieved 17 June 2013.</ref> He made two appearances in the group stage of the U20 World Cup, against [[Chile national under-20 football team|Chile]] and [[Egypt national under-20 football team|Egypt]]. Pritchard received his first call into the [[England national under-21 football team|U21]] squad on 28 August 2014 and made his debut in a 1–0 [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|2015 European U21 Championship]] [[2015 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification|qualifying]] victory over [[Lithuania national under-21 football team|Lithuania]] on 5 September, coming on for [[Nathan Redmond]] after 79 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/alex-pritchard-england-august-2014-1880973.aspx|title=Brentford attacking midfield player Alex Pritchard named in England Under-21 squad|author=Chris Wickham|publisher=|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/alex-pritchard-england-vs-lithuania-05.09.14-1900213.aspx|title=Alex Pritchard England Under 21 Lithuania|author=Ciaran Brett|publisher=|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> Pritchard made his first U21 start on his fourth cap, starting in a friendly versus [[France national under-21 football team|France]] on 17 November.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brentfordfc.co.uk/news/article/alex-pritchard-england-under-21-v-france-17.11.14-2089010.aspx|title=Brentford attacking midfield player Alex Pritchard plays for England's Under-21 side against France|author=Chris Wickham|publisher=|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> He was replaced by [[Danny Ings]] at half time during the 3–2 defeat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/under-21/2014/nov/france-report-171114|title=France 3–2 England: Under-21 International match report – England – The FA|author=The Football Association|publisher=|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref> In mid-December, Pritchard received a 2014 England U21 Player of the Year award nomination.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/under-21/2014/dec/poty-alex-pritchard-111214|title=England Under-21s Player of the Year contender: Alex Pritchard – England – The FA|author=The Football Association|publisher=|accessdate=30 December 2014}}</ref>
==Personal life== Pritchard was born in the village of [[Orsett]], and grew up in [[Thurrock]], [[Essex]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hereisthecity.com/2012/10/26/mn-how-good-is-tottenham-hotspurs-nextgen-series-star-alex-pritc/|title=How good is Tottenham Hotspur's NextGen Series star Alex Pritchard?|publisher=hereisthecity.com|date=26 October 2012|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref> He attended [[Belhus Chase Specialist Humanities College]] in [[Aveley]] prior to signing for West Ham United.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yourthurrock.com/2011/09/28/ormiston-alexs-star-on-the-rise-for-tottenham/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111223145954/http://www.yourthurrock.com/2011/09/28/ormiston-alexs-star-on-the-rise-for-tottenham/|archivedate=2011-12-23|title=Ormiston Alex's star on the rise for Tottenham|publisher=yourthurrock.com|date=28 August 2011|accessdate=1 February 2013}}</ref>

{{about|the Danish defender|the Danish striker|Mathias Jørgensen (footballer, born 2000)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Mathias Jørgensen | image = Chelsea 1 Huddersfield 1 (Mathias Jørgensen) (cropped).jpg | image_size = | caption = Jørgensen playing for [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] in 2018 | fullname = Mathias Jattah-Njie Jørgensen<ref name=BDFutbol>{{cite web |url=https://www.bdfutbol.com/en/j/j25335.html |title=Jørgensen: Mathias Jattah-Njie Jørgensen: Player |publisher=BDFutbol |accessdate=2 May 2018}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1990|4|23|df=y}}<ref name=BDFutbol/> | birth_place = [[Copenhagen]], Denmark<ref name=BDFutbol/> | height = 1.91 m<ref name=BDFutbol/> | position = [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|Centre back]] | currentclub = [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] | clubnumber = 25 | youthyears1 = 1994–2007 |youthclubs1 = [[Boldklubben af 1893|B.93]] | years1 = 2007–2012 |clubs1 = [[F.C. Copenhagen|Copenhagen]] |caps1 = 92 |goals1 = 6 | years2 = 2012–2014 |clubs2 = [[PSV Eindhoven]] |caps2 = 14 |goals2 = 2 | years3 = 2013–2014 |clubs3 = [[Jong PSV]] |caps3 = 7 |goals3 = 1 | years4 = 2014–2017 |clubs4 = [[F.C. Copenhagen|Copenhagen]] |caps4 = 93 |goals4 = 4 | years5 = 2017– |clubs5 = [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] |caps5 = 57 |goals5 = 3 | nationalyears1 = 2006 |nationalteam1 = Denmark U16 |nationalcaps1 = 1 |nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2006–2007 |nationalteam2 = [[Denmark national under-17 football team|Denmark U17]] |nationalcaps2 = 3 |nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2007 |nationalteam3 = Denmark U18 |nationalcaps3 = 1 |nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2008–2012 |nationalteam4 = [[Denmark national under-21 football team|Denmark U21]] |nationalcaps4 = 15 |nationalgoals4 = 1 | nationalyears5 = 2008– |nationalteam5 = [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] |nationalcaps5 = 19 |nationalgoals5 = 1 | club-update = 09:46, 3 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 00:13, 17 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''Mathias Jattah-Njie Jørgensen''' ({{IPA-da|ˈjɶɐ̯n̩sn̩}}; born 23 April 1990), commonly known as '''Zanka''', is a Danish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|centre back]] for the {{English football updater|HuddersT}} club [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] and the [[Denmark national football team|Denmark national team]].
He began his career at boyhood club [[F.C. Copenhagen|FC Copenhagen]], playing regularly in five [[Danish Superliga|Superliga]] seasons, before a move to [[PSV Eindhoven]] in 2012, where he spent two seasons in the Eredivisie before returning to Denmark after finding his chances limited. He joined Huddersfield Town in July 2017 for a fee of £3.5 million.
Formerly an international at under-16, [[Denmark national under-17 football team|under-17]], under-18 and [[Denmark national under-21 football team|under-21 level]], Jørgensen made his senior international debut for [[Denmark national football team|Denmark]] aged 18 in November 2008.
==Career== ===FC Copenhagen=== Born to a Danish mother and a Gambian father, Jørgensen moved to [[FC Copenhagen]] from neighbouring club [[Boldklubben af 1893|B.93]], where he had played in first-team matches even at the young age of 16. He signed a three-year contract with FCK on 26 June 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fck.dk/index.php?pageid=754&newsid=6907|title=Stortalent til F.C. København|publisher=[[F.C. Copenhagen]]|date=26 June 2007|accessdate=26 June 2007|language=Danish}}</ref> Before signing with the Danish champions, he had visited [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] for a one-week trial.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tipsbladet.dk/nyhed/sas-liga/%C2%BBzanka%C2%AB-kastede-haandtegn-med-thierry-henry |title=Lørdagstræning i PARKEN |publisher=[[TV 2 Sport (Denmark)|TV 2 Sport]] |date=25 November 2008 |accessdate=20 February 2010 |language=Danish}}</ref>
On 21 July 2007, Jørgensen strained the inner ligament in the left knee in a reserve team match – less than a month after he moved to the club.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fck.dk/nyhedsvisning/?newsid=7075 |title=Lørdagstræning i PARKEN |publisher=[[F.C. Copenhagen]] |date=18 August 2007 |accessdate=29 September 2007 |language=Danish}}</ref> On 9 September, he played again for the reserve team.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://fck.dk/nyhedsvisning/?newsid=7164 |title=Christiansen: – Bedre dag for dag |publisher=[[F.C. Copenhagen]] |date=11 September 2007 |accessdate=29 September 2007 |language=Danish }}</ref> His first team debut came on 26 September 2007 in a [[Danish Cup|cup]] match against [[FC Fredericia]]. He substituted [[Oscar Wendt]] 5 minutes before full-time, in the match FCK won 3–1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fck.dk/index.php?pageid=1791&msa=summary |title=26.09. FC Fredericia – F.C. København (Kampreferat) |publisher=[[F.C. Copenhagen]] |date=26 September 2007 |accessdate=29 September 2007 |language=Danish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903061300/http://fck.dk/index.php?pageid=1791&msa=summary |archivedate=3 September 2009 |df= }}</ref> Three days later he got his [[Danish Superliga|Superliga]] debut, this time replacing [[Hjalte Nørregaard]] about 15 minutes before full-time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fck.dk/index.php?pageid=1680&msa=summary |title=29.09. F.C. København – Lyngby Boldklub (Kampreferat) |publisher=[[F.C. Copenhagen]] |date=29 September 2007 |accessdate=29 September 2007 |language=Danish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901145646/http://fck.dk/index.php?pageid=1680&msa=summary |archivedate=1 September 2009 |df= }}</ref>
Only 8 days after his first team debut, Jørgensen was thrown on pitch in the [[extra time]] of the [[UEFA Cup]] first round second leg at [[Parken Stadium]] against [[RC Lens]], after captain [[Michael Gravgaard]] had received a red card. He was substituted for [[Marcus Allbäck]] and played in the central defence together with [[Brede Hangeland]], and they prevented any more goals for Lens, when they were 10 against 11.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://fck.dk/index.php?pageid=1798&msa=summary |title=04.10. F.C. København – RC Lens (Kampreferat) |publisher=[[F.C. Copenhagen]] |date=4 October 2007 |accessdate=6 October 2007 |language=Danish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903054237/http://fck.dk/index.php?pageid=1798&msa=summary |archivedate=3 September 2009 |df= }}</ref>
On 19 November 2008, he made his debut for the [[Danish national football team]] in a friendly against [[Wales national football team|Wales]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bold.dk/nyt/Bellamy-matchvinder-i-Broendby |title=Bellamy matchvinder i Brøndby |publisher=[[bold.dk]] |date=19 November 2008 |accessdate=20 February 2010 |language=Danish }}</ref>
After [[Roland Nilsson]] became manager for [[F.C. Copenhagen|Copenhagen]] he became captain for "The Lions". 22 February 2012 it was announced that Jørgensen would join Dutch club [[PSV Eindhoven]] on a free transfer during the summer transfer window.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=1758187.html |title=Jørgensen agrees to swap København for PSV |work=uefa.com |date=23 February 2012 |accessdate=14 May 2012}}</ref>
===PSV=== Jørgensen was featured in an unofficial pre-season tournament, The Polish Masters, in July 2012 and scored his first goal for PSV in their game against [[S.L. Benfica]] on 22 July. However, he struggled to break into PSV's first XI and only played 14 matches for the club over the course of two years.
===Return to FC Copenhagen=== On 7 July 2014, Jørgensen returned to his former team [[FC Copenhagen]] for a fee of around 600,000 Euros.<ref>{{cite web|title=Officielt: FCK henter Zanka hjem|url=http://sporten.tv2.dk/2014-07-07-officielt-fck-henter-zanka-hjem|accessdate=7 June 2014}}</ref>
===Huddersfield Town=== On 7 July 2017, Huddersfield Town confirmed the signing of Jørgensen from FC Copenhagen for £3.5 million on a three-year contract.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.htafc.com/news/2017/july/transfer-mathias-jorgensen-joins-town/ |title=TRANSFER: MATHIAS JØRGENSEN JOINS TOWN |publisher=Huddersfield Town A.F.C. |accessdate=7 July 2017}}</ref>
==International career== In May 2018 he was named in Denmark's preliminary 35-man [[Denmark national football team|squad]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] in Russia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/amp/news/revealed-every-world-cup-2018-squad-23-man-preliminary-lists/oa0atsduflsv1nsf6oqk576rb|title=Revealed: Every World Cup 2018 squad - Final 23-man lists - Goal.com|publisher=}}</ref>
==Personal life== Jørgensen dated with Hungarian model [[Enikő Mihalik]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hir24.hu/bulvar/2014/07/15/mihalik-eniko-megtalalta-az-igazit/|title=Mihalik Enikő megtalálta az igazit|date=15 July 2014|publisher=}}</ref>
==Nickname== Jørgensen received his nickname, "Zanka", from the movie [[Cool Runnings]], in which the character played by [[Doug E. Doug]] is named Sanka.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sporten.dk/fodbold/fra-til-z-som-zanka-8 |title=Fra A til Z som Zanka |publisher=[[sporten.dk]] |date=10 February 2010 |accessdate=20 February 2010 |language=Danish }}</ref> The nickname was coined by Johan Lange in 2000, while both Lange and Jørgensen were playing for [[Boldklubben af 1893|B.93]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tipsbladet.dk/artikel/manden-bag-zanka |title=Manden bag Zanka |publisher=[[tipsbladet.dk]] |accessdate=20 August 2017 |language=Danish }}</ref> Lange would go on to be one of the assistant managers during Jørgensen's first spell at FC Copenhagen, and he would later serve as the technical director when Jørgensen returned to the club in 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fck.dk/node/30537 |title=Johan Lange |publisher=[[F. C. København]] |accessdate=20 August 2017 |language=Danish }}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Erik Durm | image = Erik Durm IMG 1748.jpg | caption = Durm with [[Borussia Dortmund]] in 2014 | fullname = Erik Durm<ref>{{Cite news | title = 2014 FIFA World Cup Brazil: List of Players | url = http://www.fifadata.com/document/fwc/2014/pdf/fwc_2014_squadlists.pdf | publisher = FIFA | format = PDF | page = 16 | date = 11 June 2014 | accessdate = 11 June 2014}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1992|05|12|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Pirmasens]], Germany | height = {{height|m=1.83}} | position = [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|Left back]] / [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|Right back]] | currentclub = [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] | clubnumber = 37 | youthyears1 = 1997–2008 | youthclubs1 = SG Rieschweiler | youthyears2 = 2008–2010 | youthclubs2 = [[1. FC Saarbrücken|Saarbrücken]] | youthyears3 = 2010–2011 | youthclubs3 = [[1. FSV Mainz 05|Mainz]] | years1 = 2010–2012 | clubs1 = [[1. FSV Mainz 05 II|Mainz II]] | caps1 = 33 | goals1 = 13 | years2 = 2012–2015 | clubs2 = [[Borussia Dortmund II]] | caps2 = 32 | goals2 = 2 | years3 = 2013–2018 | clubs3 = [[Borussia Dortmund]] | caps3 = 64 | goals3 = 2 | years4 = 2018– | clubs4 = [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] | caps4 = 16 | goals4 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2011 | nationalteam1 = [[Germany national youth football team|Germany U19]] | nationalcaps1 = 2 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalyears2 = 2011 | nationalteam2 = [[Germany national under-20 football team|Germany U20]] | nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2013–2014 | nationalteam3 = [[Germany national under-21 football team|Germany U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 5 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2014– | nationalteam4 = [[Germany national football team|Germany]] | nationalcaps4 = 7 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | club-update = 09:57, 3 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 13:56, 19 November 2014 (UTC) | medaltemplates = {{medalTeam|[[Borussia Dortmund]]}} {{medalW|[[DFL-Supercup]]|[[2013 DFL-Supercup|2013]]}} {{medalW|[[DFL-Supercup]]|[[2014 DFL-Supercup|2014]]}} {{medalW|[[DFB-Pokal]]| [[2016–17 DFB-Pokal|2016–17]]}} {{Medal|Team|{{fb|Germany}}}} {{Medal|W|[[FIFA World Cup]]|[[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014]]}} }} '''Erik Durm''' (born 12 May 1992) is a German professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|full-back]] for [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] and the [[Germany national football team|German national team]]. He made his senior debut for Germany in 2014, and later that year was part of their squad which won the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]].
He has also played for [[1. FC Saarbrücken|Saarbrücken]], [[1. FSV Mainz 05|Mainz]] and [[Borussia Dortmund]].
==Club career==
===Early career=== Durm began his club career in 1998 at the academy of SG Rieschweiler, before joining the academy of [[1. FC Saarbrücken]] in 2008 where he became youth league top scorer of the 2009–2010 season with 13 goals.<ref name="pfaelzischer-merkur.de">{{cite web | url =http://www.pfaelzischer-merkur.de/sport/art27519,3173713#.UAgfO5HluSp|title = Der Traum von der Karriere als Fußballprofi | trans-title = The dream of a career as a professional football player | publisher = Pfälzischer Merkur | language=German | accessdate = 5 October 2013 | first = Andreas | last = Faas}}</ref> In July 2010, Durm was enrolled at the academy of [[1. FSV Mainz 05]] and won the 2010–11 Youth Federation Cup in Germany and Durm debuted and played his only game of the 2010–11 season for the second team of 1. FSV Mainz 05 on 4 December 2010 against [[SV Elversberg]] in the German [[Regionalliga]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.weltfussball.de/spielbericht/regionalliga-west-2010-2011-1-fsv-mainz-05-ii-sv-07-elversberg/ | title = 1. FSV Mainz 05 II 1:1 SV 07 Elversberg | language = German | publisher = weltfussball.de | date = 4 December 2010 | accessdate = 5 October 2013}}</ref>
In the 2011–12 season, Durm succeeded to the second team of 1. FSV Mainz 05 and scored seven goals in [[1. FSV Mainz 05 II]]'s and his first 10 games. Then Durm went on to score two goals in a 1. FSV Mainz 05 II 3–0 away win on matchday 7 against the second team of [[Eintracht Frankfurt]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/regionalliga/startseite/558883/artikel_durm_torjaeger-begeistert-mainz.html | title = Durm: Torjäger begeistert Mainz | trans-title = Durm: Scorer inspires Mainz | language = German | publisher = kicker.de | date = 7 October 2011 | accessdate = 5 October 2013}}</ref> Following the scoring of nine goals in the first half of the 2011–12 season, Durm scored four goals in the second half of the 2011–12 season and in January 2012, both 1. FSV Mainz 05 and Borussia Dortmund offered Durm a professional contract,<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.allgemeine-zeitung.de/sport/top-clubs/mainz-05/11546703.htm | title = Mainz 05: Profiangebot für Erik Durm - Regionalliga-Stürmer zögert noch | trans-title = Mainz 05: Professional contract offer for Erik Durm - Regionalliga forward hesitates | language = German | publisher = [[Allgemeine Zeitung (Mainz)|Allgemeine Zeitung]] | date = 9 January 2012 | accessdate = 5 October 2013 | first = Jens | last = Grützner}}</ref> but Durm declined the offer from 1. FSV Mainz 05 to sign with BVB.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.allgemeine-zeitung.de/sport/top-clubs/mainz-05/11604757.htm | title = Rätselraten um Zukunft von Erik Durm: Von Mainz 05 zum BVB - oder auch nicht | trans-title = Guesswork about the future of Erik Durm: from 1. FSV Mainz 05 to Borussia Dortmund - or not | language = German | publisher = [[Allgemeine Zeitung (Mainz)|Allgemeine Zeitung]] | date = 27 January 2012 | accessdate = 5 October 2013 | first = Jens | last = Grützner}}</ref>
===Borussia Dortmund=== In the 2012–13 season, Durm signed a contract with [[Borussia Dortmund]] until June 2014 and Durm was inducted into [[Borussia Dortmund II]] competing in the German [[3. Liga|third league]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.bvb.de/?%EF%8C%ECZ%1B%E7%F4%9C%5Ej%E7%82%9A | title = Erik Durm wechselt von Mainz 05 zum BVB | trans-title = Erik Durm moves from Mainz 05 to BVB | language = German | publisher = Borussia Dortmund | date = 1 February 2012 | accessdate = 5 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ruhrnachrichten.de/sport/bvb/amateure/art2108,1542360 | title = Erik Durm auf dem Weg zum BVB | trans-title = Erik Durm on the way to BVB | language = German | publisher = RuhrNachrichten.de | date = 30 January 2012 | accessdate = 5 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.goal.com/de/news/968/transfermarkt/2012/02/01/2879875/borussia-dortmund-u20-nationalspieler-erik-durm-kommt-vom | title = Borussia Dortmund: U20-Nationalspieler Erik Durm kommt vom FSV Mainz 05 | trans-title = Borussia Dortmund: U20 player Erik Durm comes from FSV Mainz 05 | language = German | publisher = goal.com | date = 1 February 2012 | accessdate = 5 October 2013 | first = Claas | last = Philipp}}</ref> In the [[2012–13 3. Liga|2012–13 3. Liga season]], on 21 July 2012, Durm made his professional football debut in a game for Borussia Dortmund II against [[VfL Osnabrück]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/3liga/spieltag/3-liga/2012-13/1/1443746/spielbericht_vfl-osnabrueck-45_borussia-dortmund-ii-1291.html | title = VfL durch Manno und Zoller mit Auftaktsdreier | trans-title = VfL due to Manno and Zoller with opening three points | language = German | publisher = kicker.de | date = 27 July 2013 | accessdate = 5 October 2013}}</ref> On 18 May 2013, Durm featured in the 38th and last matchday in a 1–0 away win over the second team of [[VfB Stuttgart]].
In the 2013–14 Bundesliga season, Durm was inducted into Borussia Dortmund's first team and, on 10 August 2013, debuted for BVB in the Bundesliga; coming on in the 87th minute for [[Robert Lewandowski]] as a substitute in BVB's 4–0 win over [[FC Augsburg]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.kicker.de/news/fussball/bundesliga/spieltag/1-bundesliga/2013-14/1/1894565/spielbericht_fc-augsburg-91_borussia-dortmund-17.html | title = Dreierpack: Aubameyangs toller Einstand | trans-title = Triple Pack: Aubameyang's great debut | language = German | publisher = kicker.de | date = 10 August 2013 | accessdate = 5 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title= Augsburg : Dortmund 0-4 (0-1) |url=http://www.bundesliga.com/en/stats/matchday/?matchid=145159&season=2013&liga=51&round=1 |publisher = bundesliga.com | date = 10 August 2013 | accessdate = 13 August 2013}}</ref> Durm debuted in the UEFA Champions League on 1 October 2013 in a 3–0 victory over French club Olympique Marseille.
At the start of the 2014–15 season, Durm came on as a substitute in the [[2014 DFL-Supercup]].<ref name="2014 German Super Cup">{{cite news|title=Aubameyang köpft BVB zum Supercup-Sieg|url=http://www.kicker.de/d-supercup-fb-1/2014/1/2396815/spielbericht_bayern-muenchen-14_borussia-dortmund-17.html|accessdate=25 August 2014|publisher=kicker|date=11 August 2014|language=German}}</ref> He scored his first [[Bundesliga]] goal in a 2-0 victory over [[Hertha Berlin]] on 9 May 2015.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.goal.com/en/match/borussia-dortmund-vs-hertha-bsc/1713945/report | title = Borussia Dortmund 2-0 Hertha Berlin: Subotic and Durm give hosts vital win | publisher = goal.com | date = 9 May 2015 | accessdate = 9 May 2015}}</ref>
=== Huddersfield Town === On 13 July 2018, it was announced that Durm had completed a transfer to [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.htafc.com/news/2018/july/transfer-erik-durm-joins-from-dortmund/|title=TRANSFER: ERIK DURM JOINS FROM DORTMUND!|access-date=2018-07-13|language=en-gb}}</ref> Durm signed a one-year contract, with the club having the option to extend for a further year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.examiner.co.uk/sport/football/news/huddersfield-town-sign-world-cup-14907526|title=Huddersfield Town sign World Cup winner Erik Durm for undisclosed fee|last=Benson|first=Rory|date=2018-07-13|work=huddersfieldexaminer|access-date=2018-07-13}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Erik Durm20140714 0009 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Durm celebrating Germany's win at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup Final|2014 World Cup final]].]]
===Youth=== Durm played in 2011 for both the [[Germany national under-19 football team|German under-19 team]] and the [[Germany national under-20 football team|German under-20 team]]; and he debuted for the under-19 team on 31 May 2011, coached by [[Matan Öz]], in a 3–0 victory against [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]], and scored two goals.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dfb.de/index.php?id=504292&spielid=156&action=schema&teama=Deutschland&teamb=Ungarn |title=Deutschland - Ungarn |trans-title=Germany - Hungary |language=German |publisher=dfb.de |date=31 May 2011 |accessdate=5 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131005004714/https://www.dfb.de/index.php?id=504292&spielid=156&action=schema&teama=Deutschland&teamb=Ungarn |archivedate=5 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> On 12 November 2011, Durm debuted for the German under-20 team against [[Poland national under-20 football team|Poland]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dfb.de/index.php?id=504295&spielid=86&action=schema&teama=Polen&teamb=Deutschland |title=Polen - Deutschland |trans-title=Poland - Germany |language=German |publisher=dfb.de |date=12 November 2011 |accessdate=5 October 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004232749/https://www.dfb.de/index.php?id=504295&spielid=86&action=schema&teama=Polen&teamb=Deutschland |archivedate=4 October 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> Durm debuted for the [[Germany national under-21 football team|German under-21 team]] on 13 August 2013, in a 0–0 draw against [[France national under-21 football team|France]].
===Senior=== On 1 June 2014, Durm debuted for the [[Germany national football team|German senior team]] in a 2–2 draw against [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]] at the [[Borussia-Park]] in [[Mönchengladbach]]. He played 85 minutes before being substituted for [[Benedikt Höwedes]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Germany 2-2 Cameroon: Hosts pegged back by Choupo-Moting in thrilling climax|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/germany-vs-cameroon/1630380/report|accessdate=30 April 2015|work=Goal.com|date=1 June 2014}}</ref> The following day, he was named in Germany's squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/germany/10810439/Germany-World-Cup-2014-squad.html|title=Germany World Cup 2014 squad|date=2 June 2014|accessdate=22 June 2014|work=The Telegraph}}</ref> The team won the tournament with Durm as an unused substitute for all of the games.
{{clear}}
==Career statistics==
